title: CLAUDE.md
text: file provides guidance Claude Code (claude.ai/code) working code repository.

title: CLAUDE.md
text: femtograd R package implementing automatic differentiation (AD) via backpropagation using computational graphs. ’s inspired Karpathy’s micrograd implemented R using R6 classes. focus pedagogy modern statistics rather large-scale ML. Key capabilities: - First-order gradients via reverse-mode AD (backpropagation) - Second-order derivatives (Hessians) via forward--reverse AD - Built-log-likelihood functions exponential family distributions - MLE optimization Newton-Raphson gradient ascent - Statistical inference utilities (standard errors, confidence intervals)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: package uses directed acyclic graph (DAG) represent mathematical expressions: data: Numeric matrix (values matrices internally) grad: Gradient matrix (dimensions data) backward_fn: Function defining local gradient computation prev: List parent nodes Operations: S3 methods differentiable operations (+, -, *, /, ^, log, exp, sqrt, sin, cos, lgamma, digamma, sigmoid, etc.)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Second derivatives computed via forward--reverse mode: dual: Class forward-mode AD. Stores (primal, tangent) pairs. Creating dual numbers value-object primals tangents Running forward pass (builds primal tangent graphs) tangent expression represents df/dθᵢ Running backward tangent gives d²f/dθⱼdθᵢ

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Log-likelihoods: loglik_normal, loglik_exponential, loglik_poisson, loglik_binomial, loglik_gamma, loglik_beta Optimization: gradient_ascent, gradient_descent, newton_raphson, bfgs, lbfgs Model fitting: fit() returns femtofit object standard R generics Inference: coef(), vcov(), confint(), logLik(), AIC(), BIC(), summary()

title: CLAUDE.md
code: devtools::document()  # Generate roxygen2 docs devtools::build() devtools::install()

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Test files: - test-ops.R: Arithmetic, transcendentals, activation functions - test-numerical-gradients.R: Gradient validation via finite differences - test-math-ops.R: lgamma, digamma, sin, cos, etc. - test-dual.R: Forward-mode AD dual number operations - test-hessian.R: Hessian computation - test-distributions.R: Log-likelihood functions - test-optimize.R: Optimization MLE routines - test-fit.R: fit() function femtofit class R generics - test-analytical.R: Known gradients/Hessians (power rule, chain rule, etc.) - test-stability.R: Numerical stability utilities (logsumexp, softmax, etc.)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Pedagogy performance: Code written clarity, speed Statistics focus: Designed MLE, Hessians, inference rather deep learning Base R generics: Uses standard R generics (coef, vcov, confint, logLik) interoperability Matrix representation: values matrices internally (see DESIGN.md) Graph Construction: Operations automatically build computational graphs Lazy Gradient Computation: Gradients computed backward() call Gradient Accumulation: Parent node gradients accumulate multiple children

title: CLAUDE.md
text: data stored matrices (see DESIGN.md rationale): - Scalars 1×1 matrices - Vectors n×1 column matrices - Matrices m×n matrices
code: val(5)           # 1×1 matrix internally val(c(1,2,3))    # 3×1 column matrix internally data(x)          # Returns scalar for 1×1 (drop=TRUE default) data(x, drop=FALSE)  # Always returns matrix

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Scalar (1×1) matrices broadcast larger matrices:
code: a <- val(2)           # 1×1 x <- val(c(1,2,3))    # 3×1 y <- a * x            # 3×1: c(2,4,6) backward(y) grad(a)  # Scalar: sum of gradients = 6 grad(x)  # 3×1: c(2,2,2)

title: CLAUDE.md
text: R dispatches S3 methods based first argument. However, femtograd now handles orderings:
code: x <- val(5) x * 2     # Works: dispatches to *.value 2 * x     # Also works: scalar is converted to value internally

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # WRONG: Creates new value, breaks graph rate <- rate + lr * grad(rate)  # CORRECT: Update data in place data(rate) <- data(rate) + lr * grad(rate)

title: CLAUDE.md
code: loss_fn <- function(p) {   mu <- p[[1]]   sigma <- p[[2]]   loglik_normal(mu, sigma, data) } params <- list(val(0), val(1)) H <- hessian(loss_fn, params) se <- std_errors(H, is_loglik = TRUE)

title: CLAUDE.md
code: # Define log-likelihood with named parameters # Use log-parameterization for constrained parameters (e.g., sigma > 0) result <- fit(   function(mu, log_sigma) {     sigma <- exp(log_sigma)     loglik_normal(mu, sigma, data)   },   params = c(mu = 0, log_sigma = 0) )  # Standard R generics coef(result)      # Named parameter estimates vcov(result)      # Variance-covariance matrix confint(result)   # 95% confidence intervals se(result)        # Standard errors logLik(result)    # Log-likelihood (works with AIC/BIC) AIC(result)       # Akaike information criterion summary(result)   # Full summary with z-values and p-values

title: CLAUDE.md
code: result <- find_mle(loglik_fn, initial_params) result$estimate  # MLE values result$se        # Standard errors result$vcov      # Variance-covariance matrix

title: CLAUDE.md
text: constrained parameters, use transformations:
code: # sigma > 0: use log_sigma, then exp(log_sigma) in likelihood # 0 < p < 1: use logit_p, then sigmoid(logit_p) in likelihood  result <- fit(   function(mu, log_sigma) {     sigma <- exp(log_sigma)  # Ensures sigma > 0     loglik_normal(mu, sigma, data)   },   params = c(mu = 0, log_sigma = 0) )  # To get sigma estimate: exp(coef(result)["log_sigma"])

title: femtograd Design Decisions
text: values femtograd use matrix representation internally. document explains .

title: femtograd Design Decisions
text: Early versions femtograd inconsistent return types: unpredictability made API difficult use correctly. Users couldn’t know whether grad() return scalar, vector, something else without tracing entire computation.
code: x <- val(3) y <- val(c(1, 2, 3)) z <- x + c(1, 2, 3)  # scalar val + vector  data(x)    # scalar data(y)    # vector data(z)    # vector (from broadcasting) grad(x)    # scalar or vector, depending on computation graph

title: femtograd Design Decisions
text: Standardize matrices. Everything 2-dimensional: Scalars 1×1 matrices Column vectors n×1 matrices Row vectors 1×n matrices Matrices m×n matrices means: - data() always returns matrix - grad() always returns matrix (dimensions value) - hessian() always returns matrix (p×p p parameters)

title: femtograd Design Decisions
text: considered full tensor support (arbitrary n-dimensional arrays) rejected : 1. Statistical applications don’t need target use cases maximum likelihood estimation, Fisher information, Hessian computation, gradient-based optimization. involve: Scalar loss functions Vector parameters (p×1) Hessian matrices (p×p) Variance-covariance matrices (p×p) standard statistical computation requires 3+ dimensional tensors. 2. Pedagogy generality femtograd exists teach automatic differentiation concepts clearly. Tensors introduce: Shape algebra broadcasting rules Stride calculations memory layout View vs. copy semantics Einsum notation contractions obscure core AD concepts (computational graphs, chain rule, forward/reverse modes) behind implementation complexity. 3. R already tensor autodiff torch package provides GPU-accelerated tensors full autodiff support. Users needing tensor operations use . femtograd competing PyTorch—’s teaching tool statistics. 4. Implementation simplicity Matrix operations R well-supported fast (BLAS/LAPACK). Implementing custom tensor library substantial work little benefit use case.

title: femtograd Design Decisions
text: follow standard mathematical conventions: Parameters: Column vectors (p×1) Gradients: shape value (p×1 parameter vectors) Jacobians: f: ℝⁿ → ℝᵐ, J m×n Hessians: Square matrices (p×p) Fisher information: Square matrices (p×p)

title: femtograd Design Decisions
code: # Single parameter (1×1) theta <- val(matrix(5, 1, 1))  # Multiple parameters (p×1 column vector) params <- val(matrix(c(mu, sigma), ncol = 1))  # Gradient has same shape as value grad(params)  # p×1 matrix  # Hessian is p×p hessian(loss_fn, params)  # p×p matrix

title: femtograd Design Decisions
text: gain: - Predictable API behavior - Clear dimension semantics - Alignment mathematical notation - Simpler implementation lose: - Convenience implicit scalar handling - R-idiomatic flexibility (e.g., val(5) without explicit matrix) - Higher-dimensional operations (rarely needed statistics)

title: femtograd Design Decisions
text: convenience, val() accepts scalars vectors converts matrices internally: preserves simple API maintaining internal consistency. Smart dropping: default, data() grad() return scalars 1×1 matrices (using drop=TRUE). means scalar operations work naturally: explicit matrix returns, use drop=FALSE:
code: val(5)           # becomes 1×1 matrix val(c(1, 2, 3))  # becomes 3×1 column vector x <- val(3) y <- x^2 backward(y) data(y)   # Returns 9 (scalar), not matrix(9, 1, 1) grad(x)   # Returns 6 (scalar) data(x, drop = FALSE)  # Returns 1×1 matrix

title: femtograd Design Decisions
text: Scalar (1×1) matrices broadcast larger matrices element-wise operations: essential statistical operations like lambda * x exponential distributions.
code: a <- val(2)           # 1×1 matrix x <- val(c(1, 2, 3))  # 3×1 matrix y <- a * x            # 3×1 matrix: c(2, 4, 6)  backward(y) grad(a)  # Scalar: sum of all gradients = 6 grad(x)  # 3×1 matrix: c(2, 2, 2)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Alexander Towell. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Towell (2026). femtograd: Automatic Differentiation Statistical Computing. R package version 0.3.0.
code: @Manual{,   title = {femtograd: Automatic Differentiation for Statistical Computing},   author = {Alexander Towell},   year = {2026},   note = {R package version 0.3.0}, }

title: Automatic Differentiation for Statistical Computing
text: Automatic differentiation statistical computing R. femtograd provides reverse-mode AD (backpropagation) first-order gradients forward--reverse AD Hessian computation. Designed pedagogy modern statistics rather large-scale ML.

title: Automatic Differentiation for Statistical Computing
text: Reverse-mode AD: Efficient gradient computation via backpropagation Forward--reverse AD: Second-order derivatives (Hessians) Newton-Raphson Fisher information Log-likelihood functions: Exponential family distributions (normal, exponential, Poisson, binomial, gamma, beta, negative binomial, logistic, Bernoulli) MLE optimization: Gradient ascent/descent, Newton-Raphson, BFGS, L-BFGS line search Statistical inference: Standard errors, variance-covariance matrices, confidence intervals, Wald tests Numerical stability: logsumexp, softmax, safe log/division, overflow protection

title: Automatic Differentiation for Statistical Computing
code: library(femtograd)  # Generate exponential data set.seed(42) x <- rexp(100, rate = 2)  # Define log-likelihood loglik <- function(p) loglik_exponential(p[[1]], x)  # Find MLE with standard errors result <- find_mle(loglik, list(val(1)), method = "newton") result$estimate  # MLE result$se        # Standard errors

title: Automatic Differentiation for Statistical Computing
text: Create differentiable values val():
code: x <- val(3) y <- val(4) z <- x^2 + x*y  # z = 9 + 12 = 21  backward(z) grad(x)  # dz/dx = 2x + y = 10 grad(y)  # dz/dy = x = 3

title: Automatic Differentiation for Statistical Computing
text: Arithmetic: +, -, *, /, ^ Transcendental: log, exp, sqrt, sin, cos, tanh, lgamma, digamma, log1p Activations: sigmoid, relu, softplus, logit Stability: logsumexp, softmax, log_safe, div_safe, exp_safe, sigmoid_stable, log_sigmoid

title: Automatic Differentiation for Statistical Computing
code: f <- function(p) {   x <- p[[1]]   y <- p[[2]]   x^2 + x*y + y^2 }  H <- hessian(f, list(val(1), val(2))) # Returns 2x2 Hessian matrix

title: Automatic Differentiation for Statistical Computing
code: # Normal distribution loglik <- function(p) loglik_normal(p[[1]], p[[2]], data)  # Poisson distribution loglik <- function(p) loglik_poisson(p[[1]], data)  # Gamma distribution loglik <- function(p) loglik_gamma(p[[1]], p[[2]], data)

title: Automatic Differentiation for Statistical Computing
code: # Gradient ascent result <- gradient_ascent(loglik, params, lr = 0.01, max_iter = 1000)  # Newton-Raphson (uses Hessian) result <- newton_raphson(loglik, params, max_iter = 50)  # BFGS quasi-Newton result <- bfgs(loglik, params, maximize = TRUE)  # L-BFGS (memory efficient) result <- lbfgs(loglik, params, m = 10, maximize = TRUE)  # Full MLE with inference result <- find_mle(loglik, params, method = "newton")

title: Automatic Differentiation for Statistical Computing
code: result <- find_mle(loglik, params)  # Standard errors from Fisher information result$se  # Variance-covariance matrix result$vcov  # Confidence intervals confint_mle(result, level = 0.95)  # Wald test wald_test(result, null_values = c(0, 1))

title: BFGS quasi-Newton optimizer — bfgs
text: BFGS maintains approximation B inverse Hessian, updated : B_k+1 = (- ρsy') B_k (- ρys') + ρss' s = x_k+1 - x_k, y = g_k+1 - g_k, ρ = 1/(y'*s) search direction d = -B*g, followed line search.

title: Fisher scoring optimizer — fisher_scoring
text: regular exponential families, Fisher scoring equivalent Newton-Raphson since observed = expected information. Fisher scoring: θ_n+1 = θ_n + (θ_n)⁻¹ S(θ_n) = -EH (Fisher information) S = gradient (score). implementation uses observed Hessian approximation expected Hessian, making identical Newton-Raphson. true Fisher scoring implementation, one need compute EH analytically via Monte Carlo.

what: Compute Hessian matrix via forward-over-reverse automatic differentiation — hessian
title: Compute Hessian matrix via forward-over-reverse automatic differentiation — hessian
text: Computes Hessian matrix (matrix second partial derivatives) scalar function respect vector parameters. Uses forward-mode AD top reverse-mode AD efficient, accurate computation.

title: Compute Hessian matrix via forward-over-reverse automatic differentiation — hessian
Compute Hessian matrix via forward-over-reverse automatic differentiation — hessian
text: loss_fn function takes list parameters returns scalar loss/objective. function must use femtograd operations. params list value objects (parameters) value_creator Function create value objects (default: val). allows customization different value types.

title: Compute Hessian matrix via forward-over-reverse automatic differentiation — hessian
text: numeric matrix dimension (n x n) n = length(params), containing Hessian d²f/dθᵢdθⱼ

title: Compute Hessian matrix via forward-over-reverse automatic differentiation — hessian
text: Hessian computed using forward--reverse mode AD: parameter , create dual numbers : Primal = value object holding parameter value Tangent = value object (1 param , 0 others) Run loss function dual-value inputs tangent loss df/dθᵢ (value expression) Call backward() tangent loss tangent parameter's gradient gives d²f/dθⱼdθᵢ "forward--reverse" pattern: forward-mode (dual numbers) computes df/dθᵢ symbolically, reverse-mode differentiates get d²f/dθⱼdθᵢ.

title: Compute Hessian matrix via forward-over-reverse automatic differentiation — hessian
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Hessian of f(x,y) = x^2 + x*y + y^2 loss_fn <- function(p) {   x <- p[[1]]   y <- p[[2]]   x^2 + x*y + y^2 } params <- list(val(1), val(2)) H <- hessian(loss_fn, params) # H should be [[2, 1], [1, 2]] } # }

title: Likelihood Ratio Test — lrt
text: Computes likelihood ratio test (LRT) comparing nested models. Works femtofit objects raw log-likelihood values.

title: Likelihood Ratio Test — lrt
text: null_model Either femtofit object (simpler model) numeric log-likelihood value. alt_model Either femtofit object (complex model) numeric log-likelihood value. df Degrees freedom. NULL arguments femtofit objects, computed difference number parameters.

title: Likelihood Ratio Test — lrt
text: likelihood_ratio_test object (also inherits hypothesis_test) containing: stat LRT statistic: -2 * (loglik_null - loglik_alt) p.value P-value chi-squared distribution dof Degrees freedom null_loglik Log-likelihood null model alt_loglik Log-likelihood alternative model

title: Likelihood Ratio Test — lrt
text: likelihood ratio test statistic : $$\Lambda = -2 (\ell_0 - \ell_1)$$ \(\ell_0\) log-likelihood null (simpler) model \(\ell_1\) log-likelihood alternative (complex) model. null hypothesis regularity conditions, \(\Lambda\) asymptotically follows chi-squared distribution degrees freedom equal difference number free parameters.

title: Likelihood Ratio Test — lrt
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Generate data set.seed(42) x <- rnorm(100, mean = 5, sd = 2)  # Fit full model (estimate both mu and sigma) full <- fit(   function(mu, log_sigma) {     sigma <- exp(log_sigma)     loglik_normal(mu, sigma, x)   },   params = c(mu = 0, log_sigma = 0) )  # Fit null model (mu fixed at 0) null <- fit(   function(log_sigma) {     sigma <- exp(log_sigma)     loglik_normal(0, sigma, x)  # mu = 0   },   params = c(log_sigma = 0) )  # Likelihood ratio test test <- lrt(null, full) test pval(test) is_significant_at(test, 0.05)  # Can also use raw log-likelihoods lrt(null_loglik = -150, alt_loglik = -140, df = 1) } # }

title: Newton-Raphson optimizer — newton_raphson
text: Newton-Raphson update: θ_n+1 = θ_n - H⁻¹ g maximization, uses: θ_n+1 = θ_n - H⁻¹ g (H negative definite) minimization, uses: θ_n+1 = θ_n - H⁻¹ g (H positive definite) Hessian computed via forward--reverse AD iteration. exact can slow many parameters.

title: Newton-Raphson optimizer — newton_raphson
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Find MLE for normal distribution x <- rnorm(100, mean = 5, sd = 2) loglik <- function(p) loglik_normal(p[[1]], p[[2]], x) result <- newton_raphson(loglik, list(val(0), val(1))) sapply(result$params, data)  # Should be close to c(mean(x), sd(x)) } # }
